snippet: Palestinian refugees in Syria, a country that has treated them more kindly than many others, have found themselves caught up in the worsening conflict between the government and the opposition.
abstract: Palestinian refugees in Syria, a country that has treated them more kindly than many others, are being pulled into that nation’s dark struggle; brutal crackdown on the opposition by President Bashar al-Assad’s government, with more than 10,000 killed since the uprising began in March 2011, has put the Palestinians in a difficult spot, forced to choose between the popular mood and their benefactor.

byline.original: By ROD NORDLAND and DALAL MAWAD
byline.contributor: A Syrian employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Damascus.

lead_paragraph: Palestinian refugees in Syria, a country that has treated them more kindly than many others, have found themselves caught up in the worsening conflict between the government and the opposition.
